com.fraudpointer.api.models
Class Event

java.lang.Object
  com.fraudpointer.api.models.Event

public class Event
extends java.lang.Object

Event object groups a set of Data under an Event Type. This whole set, is then associated to an AssessmentSession by calling IClient.appendEventToAssessmentSession(AssessmentSession, Event)

When you are using the FraudPointer Service, you need to collect data and sent it over to FraudPointer Server. In order to do that you instantiate an Event object and then you call addData() method. Then you call IClient.appendEventToAssessmentSession(AssessmentSession, Event) and Event packaged data are sent over.

It is important, though, to instantiate the appropriate Event Type. The following event types are supported:

  • GenericEvent
  • CheckoutEvent
  • FailedPayment
  • PurchaseEvent

Field Detail

GenericEvent

public static final java.lang.String GenericEvent
Use this constant to instantiate an Event that is not one of the other types.

Usually, you group your data into a more specific Type. However, if the data that you want to group cannot be categorized below one of the specific Types, you can use the GenericEvent Type.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

CheckoutEvent

public static final java.lang.String CheckoutEvent
Use this constant to instantiate an Event that is related to Checkout data.

You can create a CheckoutEvent when you get data from a check out form. You essentially want to store in FraudPointer server the fact that your customer is trying to check out together with relevant check out data. Example of Data that you might want to store below the CheckoutEvent Type are:

  • Firstname
  • Lastname
  • Customer e-mail
  • Customer address
  • Product to Purchase
  • Price
    • - e.t.c.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

FailedPayment

public static final java.lang.String FailedPayment
Use this constant to instantiate an Event to mark a Failed Payment.

When you decide to proceed with charging your customer, with whatever data you have at your hand, your attempt to charge its credit card might fail. In that case, record this failed payment by instantiating a FailedPayment Event Type and sending it over to FraudPointer, without necessarily attaching any data to it. Only the FailedPayment Event is enough to mark the fact that the payment carried out during this session failed.
You can, and you probably should, instantiate this event many times. One for each failed payment attempt during the same assessment session.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

PurchaseEvent

public static final java.lang.String PurchaseEvent
Use this constant to instantiate an Event to mark a Successful Payment.

When you decide to proceed with charging your customer, with whatever data you have at your hand, your attempt to charge its credit card might succeed. In that case, record this successful payment by instantiating a Purchase Event Type and sending it over to FraudPointer, without necessarily attaching any data to it. Only the PurchaseEvent Event is enough to mark the fact that the payment carried out during this session has succeeded.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

type

public java.lang.String type
Event Type to send to the server for event creation.

data

public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> data
Returns the Data appended to the particular Event.

If you want to get read access to the Data that you have appended to an Event you can use this. Note that if you want to append data to the Event use one of the methods AddData()

Constructor Detail

Event

public Event(java.lang.String eventType)
Instantiate an Event by calling new on this Constructor.

Use

Event anEvent = new Event(....) to instantiate a new Event before start filling it with data. The argument should be one of the valid event types.

Parameters:
eventType - One of:
  • CheckoutEvent
  • FailedPayment
  • GenericEvent
  • PurchaseEvent
Method Detail

addData

public Event addData(java.lang.String key,
                     java.lang.String value)
Adds one datum to the particular Event.

The datum is actually a value of an Attribute and value given is a string instance or literal. Use this method if you want to add a datum of type string in your Event at hand.
Here is an example:
 
 Event anEvent = new Event(Event.CheckoutEvent);
 anEvent.addData("BILLING_COUNTRY", "FR");
 anEvent.addData("BILLING_CITY", "Paris");

Parameters:
key - KEY value of the Attribute that you want to use. The Attributes are either System or Custom Account Attributes. The System Attributes can be found in the official Fraudpointer documentation. The Custom Account Attributes should be given to you by the person who has created them in the FraudPointer Application.
value - Value of the Attribute. A string instance or literal should be given.
Returns:
The current Event instance, in order to continue adding data.

addData

public Event addData(java.lang.String key,
                     java.util.Calendar value)
Adds one datum to the particular Event.

The datum is actually a value of an Attribute and value given is a Calendar instance.

Use this method if you want to add a datum of type Calendar in your Event at hand.

Here is an example:
 
 // 30-June-2011 23:55:59 local time zone
 Calendar startDate = Calendar.getInstance();
 startDate.set(Calendar.YEAR, 2011);
 startDate.set(Calendar.MONTH, 6-1); // June
 startDate.set(Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH, 30);
 startDate.set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 23);
 startDate.set(Calendar.MINUTE, 55);
 startDate.set(Calendar.SECOND, 59);
 event.addData("StartDate", startDate);
Note that internally, the given input is converted to a string that represents a date time point using the ISO 8601 standard (extended format). Hence, the actual string sent over to Fraudpointer Server for the example given before is "2011-06-30T23:55:59+02:00" assuming a time zone 2 hours ahead of UTC.

Parameters:
key - KEY value of the Attribute that you want to use. The Attributes are either System or Custom Account Attributes. The System Attributes can be found in the official Fraudpointer documentation. The Custom Account Attributes should be given to you by the person who has created them in the FraudPointer Application.
value - Value of the Attribute. A Calendar instance should be given.
Returns:
The current Event instance, in order to continue adding data.

addData

public Event addData(java.lang.String key,
                     java.util.Date value)
Adds one datum to the particular Event.

The datum is actually a value of an Attribute and value given is a Date instance. Everything that applies to addData(String, java.util.Calendar) applies accordingly to this method too.

Parameters:
key - KEY value of the Attribute that you want to use. The Attributes are either System or Custom Account Attributes. The System Attributes can be found in the official Fraudpointer documentation. The Custom Account Attributes should be given to you by the person who has created them in the FraudPointer Application.
value - Value of the Attribute. A Date instance should be given.
Returns:
The current Event instance, in order to continue adding data.
